concern:
I'll be honest, I didn't go to college because I wanted to. I did it because I was expected to. My parents always harped on the necessity of getting a degree in order to have a better chance of getting a high-paying job. While logically I agreed with them, I couldn't get my heart into the grind.

So I spent my four years winging it. I was outstanding in some classes, mediocre in some, and near-failing in one or two.  When I was close to failing grades, my parents sat me down and made me decide: get myself together and finish college without near-failing grades happening again or drop out and get a job. I chose to grit my teeth and finish up because I didn't want college debt and nothing to show for it.

Fast forward and I finally got my degree. I wanted to get out of graduation real quick. I grabbed my paper, got my transcripts, and moved on to life. A year later, I enlisted in the Army and haven't looked back since. No, I didn't commission and become an officer. I enlisted.

I'm writing this post to reflect on college five years after obtaining my degree. I've just finished paying off all my debt, and it's only struck me now how little I cared about those four years. I barely remember the faces and names of my former peers or professors, I didn't make a single friend, and I certainly don't remember anything from what I learned. In hindsight, my college life was so indifferent.

Don't get me wrong; my degree has given me certain privileges and respect and I aim to take advantage of what I have. I'm actually at a point in life where I'm ready to willingly take the next step and get my master's degree. Still, I acknowledge that at the time I was an undergraduate, I wasn't truly ready.

For those who are done with higher education, what do you remember about your time?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about today?
I'm reflecting on my past college experiences and how disconnected I felt from them at the time. Now, I'm considering pursuing a master's degree to build on what I've learned since then.
It sounds like you've come a long way since your college days and are now considering taking the next step in your academic journey. What are you hoping to gain from pursuing a master's degree?

I hope to gain advanced skills and better career opportunities that align with my professional growth since leaving college. This time, I'm excited to engage more fully with my studies, as I've matured and am now truly motivated to learn.

It's wonderful to hear that you're eager to dive back into academia with renewed enthusiasm and purpose. It seems like you've identified areas where you want to grow and are motivated to make the most of this new educational opportunity. What are some of the challenges you anticipate as you embark on this journey?

I anticipate challenges like balancing my military commitments with the rigorous demands of graduate school, which could make it hard to stay consistent. Additionally, I worry about overcoming my old habits of disengagement to ensure I fully commit this time around.

To help you overcome these challenges, would you prefer to focus on creating a schedule that balances your military commitments and schoolwork, or would you rather explore strategies to keep yourself engaged in your studies?

I'd like to focus on exploring strategies to keep myself engaged in my studies, as building that motivation is key to overcoming my past tendencies. Once I have a solid plan for engagement, we can then address creating a schedule to balance my military commitments with schoolwork.

That sounds like a wise approach, prioritizing your engagement with your studies first. Let's brainstorm some strategies together that could help you stay motivated and fully committed throughout your master's program.

I think a good strategy for staying engaged would be to set personal, meaningful goals for each module, drawing on my current motivation to make learning feel relevant. Additionally, incorporating regular selfreflection sessions could help me monitor my progress and prevent slipping back into old habits of disengagement.

Setting personal goals and incorporating regular selfreflection sessions sound like great strategies to keep you motivated and engaged in your studies. To further support your commitment, have you considered finding an accountability partner or joining a study group to help you stay on track?

I haven't really considered finding an accountability partner or joining a study group before, as I was more isolated during my undergraduate years. Now that I'm motivated to stay engaged, I think it could be helpful to explore these options to build a supportive network and maintain my commitment.
